description: From Latin libertinus (“a freedman, prop. adj., of or belonging to the condition of a freedman”), from libertus (“a freedman”), from liber (“free”); see liberal, liberate.

entries.meaning: (historical) Someone freed from slavery in Ancient Rome; a freedman.

adjectives.description: libertine (comparative more libertine, superlative most libertine)

entries.meaning: Dissolute, licentious, profligate; loose in morals.
One who is freethinking in religious matters.
Someone (especially a man) who takes no notice of moral laws, especially those involving sexual propriety; someone loose in morals; a pleasure-seeker.
examples: So the truth of the matter is that a libertine in love, if indeed a libertine can be in love, becomes from that moment in less of a hurry to enjoy the pleasures of the flesh.
